Key Match Events: Houston fell behind early at home after giving up a run in each of the first two innings.
Spencer Arrighetti pitched into the seventh before leaving with two outs, finishing with seven strikeouts and a quality start.
The Astros didn't score until the bottom of the seventh, breaking through on Jon Singleton's RBI triple and Jose Altuve's RBI single.
Houston stranded Yainer Diaz on second base with one out in the eighth, then left runners on second and third to end the ninth with the score still tied at 2-2.
Despite getting the automatic runner, the Astros failed to bring him home for the go-ahead run in the 10th and 11th innings.
In the 12th, the A's bunted their runner home, plating two runs on three consecutive bunts.
Houston got one back in their half of the frame, but left the tying run on third with one out, losing 4-3.
The Astros left 13 men on base and went 2-for-17 with runners in scoring position.
Post-Match Reflections: It's unclear why Houston keeps falling short in extra innings, especially for a team that prioritizes batting average and limits strikeouts.
Maybe it's bad luck, or maybe they're trying too hard.
Maybe they should try Oakland's strategy of bunting at every pitch.
Or maybe 54 games just isn't a large enough sample size.
Still, they'd be even better if they could just win in extra innings.
